text: Eden Park, Cincinnati Art MuseumLewis Henry Meakin (12 July 1850U.S. Passport Applications, 1795-1925 - 4 August 1917) was an English-American Impressionist landscape artist. Born in Newcastle, England, he moved to Cincinnati, Ohio with his family in 1863. After studying art in Europe he returned to Cincinnati where he taught at the Cincinnati Art Academy. Artist George Bellows called him “one of the best landscape painters in America." A skilled painter of landscapes, Meakin is known for his scenes along the Ohio River, the American and Canadian Rockies, and his depictions of summer in Camden, Maine and Cape Ann, Massachusetts. Meakin began working in a tonalist manner, then moved toward Impressionism around the turn of the century. From his travels to the American West where he pioneered the Impressionist-style for a new region, Meakin earned the title "Father of Western Art." He served as president of the Cincinnati Art Club from 1910 to 1912 as curator at the Cincinnati Art Museum from 1911 to 1917, where today some of his pieces are on exhibit. ==References== ==External links== * Category:1850 births Category:1917 deaths Category:Artists from Cincinnati Category:Artists from Newcastle upon Tyne Category:19th-century American painters Category:American male painters Category:20th-century American painters Category:20th-century English painters Category:American landscape painters Category:American Impressionist painters Category:English emigrants to the United States
